title: How to Use Turmeric Powder

methods.name: Using Turmeric as a Dietary Supplement

steps.headline: Take turmeric supplements to manage and treat arthritis.
steps.description: Turmeric’s anti-inflammatory properties positively impacts your immune system responses, meaning, your joints won’t swell up as much. Take 400 mg to 600 mg up to 3 times a day to lessen the symptoms of arthritis. Turmeric is especially helpful in treating rheumatoid arthritis and osteoarthritis. 1 teaspoon (4.2 grams) of turmeric powder counts as 200 mg.

steps.headline: Use turmeric to boost your brain power and memory.
steps.description: Daily turmeric can help boost a type of growth hormone in your brain that causes neurons to multiply and divide. This means you’ll have an improved memory and less of a chance of developing depression and Alzheimer’s disease. A dose of 90 to 200 mg (1 teaspoon) per day is enough to benefit your brain. Turmeric alone cannot prevent brain-related diseases, but it can delay their onset and help lessen any symptoms.

steps.headline: Make your own frozen turmeric “capsules” with honey to fight off colds.
steps.description: Mix ⅓ cup (43 grams) of turmeric powder with 3 tablespoons (44 mL) of raw honey. Use a spoon to mix and pat it into a paste then pinch off bean-sized amounts, roll them into balls, and place them on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper. Freeze them in the freezer until they’re solid (about 24 hours). Take 1 or 2 “capsules” a day to reap the benefits.

steps.headline: Combine turmeric with raw honey to boost your immune system.
steps.description: Turmeric and honey are both excellent at easing inflammation and oxidative stress, which can lead to all kinds of common illnesses (like the cold, flu, and seasonal infections). Use a spoon to mix 1 part turmeric to 3 parts honey. As an example, use about 4 teaspoons (16.8 grams) of turmeric powder for ⁄4 cup (59 mL) of raw honey. Eat 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of the superpowered honey every 2 to 3 hours when you feel a cold coming on.

steps.headline: Stir turmeric powder into tea for a dose of anti-inflammatory power.
steps.description: Make a simple tea by stirring in 1 teaspoon (4.2 grams) of turmeric powder for every 1 cup (240 mL) of boiling water. You can also add a scoop to other types of teas, like ginger, green, white, or black tea. A daily teaspoon of turmeric can help with allergies, asthma, and respiratory infections. Squeeze a lemon and some honey into the tea for a sweet, bright sipper.

methods.name: Applying Turmeric to Your Skin and Teeth

steps.headline: Make turmeric serum to clear up acne and other skin issues.
steps.description: Turmeric has anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial properties that make it perfect for fighting acne, blackheads, eczema, and psoriasis. Simply put 4 tablespoons (59 mL) of aloe vera gel, ½ teaspoon (2.1 grams) of turmeric powder, and 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of argan oil into a jar and stir it together. Massage this mixture onto your face and wash it off after 15 to 30 minutes.

steps.headline: Even out your skin tone with turmeric cream.
steps.description: Turmeric balances how much melanin your skin produces, helping create an even skin tone naturally. Blend together 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of aloe vera gel (store-bought, organic if possible), 1 tablespoon (14.3 grams) of turmeric powder, and 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of tomato juice. Massage the cream into your skin for about a minute and then let it sit for 30 minutes. Use it every day or every other day to see fast results. If you have pale skin, it’s best to use this cream up to twice a week to avoid a yellow look. But don’t worry, any yellowing is temporary.

steps.headline: Treat under-eye circles with a turmeric cream.
steps.description: Turmeric is rich in antioxidants that fight dark circles under your eyes. All you’ll need is 3 tablespoons (44 mL) of melted ghee, 1 teaspoon (4.2 grams) of turmeric powder, and 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of melted beeswax. Mix all of the ingredients in a small bowl and pour the cream into a small lidded jar. It will harden after sitting for an hour or two. Apply about 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) to your under-eye area before bedtime to wake up looking refreshed! This mixture can even decrease the appearance of wrinkles, fine lines, and sagging skin. You may need to use more beeswax if you live in a humid or hot environment.

steps.headline: Exfoliate your skin with a turmeric face and body scrub.
steps.description: Place 1/5 cup (30 g) of granulated sugar, 2 teaspoons (8.4 grams) of turmeric powder, and ⁄2 cup (120 mL) of coconut oil into a mixing bowl and stir it together until it’s smooth. Then spoon the mixture into an empty ice cube tray and let it harden in the freezer for about 5 minutes. Exfoliate by massaging a cube or two onto damp skin up to 3 times a week. Take a shower afterward to rinse away the scrub.

steps.headline: Whiten your teeth with turmeric, coconut oil, and salt toothpaste.
steps.description: Turmeric might make your food yellow, but it can actually whiten your teeth and stave off gingivitis. Stir together 3 tablespoons (42.9 grams) of turmeric powder, 3 tablespoons (42.9 grams) of salt, and enough coconut oil to turn it into a paste. Start with ⁄2 tablespoon (7.4 mL) of coconut oil, stir it, and add more ⁄8 tablespoon (1.8 mL) at a time if it’s too thick. The final toothpaste should have the same consistency as toothpaste. Keep in mind that coconut oil will melt in your mouth, so it’s better to leave it a little thicker.

steps.headline: Add turmeric powder to rice for golden color and a smoky taste.
steps.description: For every cup of rice you look, stir in ½ teaspoon (2.1 grams) of turmeric powder. So if you’re cooking 2 cups (450 g) of rice, use 1 teaspoon (4.2 grams) of turmeric powder. Toss it in the saucepan or rice cooker it along with ¼ teaspoon (1.05 grams) of salt (per cup of rice) before cooking the rice. Ginger, cumin, onion, garlic, and clove are all earthy spices that pair well with turmeric rice. Stir in ¼ teaspoon (1.05 grams) of ground ginger, ½ teaspoon (2.1 grams) of onion powder, ½ teaspoon (2.1 grams) of garlic powder, and 1 US tbsp (15 mL) of coconut oil for a balanced, rounded flavor. Substitute brown or white rice with cauliflower rice if you’re watching your carbohydrate and/or caloric intake. Add pepper to increase the absorption of turmeric.

steps.headline: Make a turmeric spice rub to add a bold, earthy flavor to meats.
steps.description:
Rubbing meats before cooking them gives them an extra layer burst of flavor and, in this case, antioxidants! You can even use it on vegan meats like tempeh and seitan or sprinkle it on vegetables. To make a rub, simply stir the following ingredients together in a small bowl until all the ingredients are well combined:
3 tablespoons (42.9 grams) of turmeric powder
2 tablespoons (28.3 grams) of garlic powder
1 tablespoon (14.3 grams) of onion powder
1 tablespoon (14.3 grams) of ground cumin
2 teaspoons (8.4 grams) of ground coriander
1 teaspoon (4.2 grams) of ground black pepper
¼ teaspoon (1.05 grams) of ground cloves

steps.headline: Add color and flavor to vegan staples for a more authentic look and taste.
steps.description: Turmeric gives your vegan dishes a burst of color, which is great if you’re making cashew cheese or tofu omelets. For the nut cheese, simply add 1 teaspoon (4.2 grams) of turmeric powder to your cashew cheese (per cup of nuts used before processing). For a yolk-colored tofu scramble, sprinkle 1 teaspoon (4.2 grams) on top of the tofu while it’s in the skillet. Finish off the scramble with a sprinkle of pepper and a few slices of avocado—the compounds in pepper and healthy fats in avocado help your body absorb more of the turmeric. Turmeric has an earthy, slightly bitter and warm taste, so you might want to use earthy spices (like ginger and cumin) and herbs (like rosemary and basil) to flavor to your tofu omelets and nut cheeses.

steps.headline: Dress salads with a bright turmeric, lemon, and ginger dressing.
steps.description:
Drizzle this bright and zesty dressing over salad greens, proteins, or roasted vegetables for a healthy dose of antioxidants. Simply blend the following ingredients in a blender until it’s smooth and runny:

⁄4 cup (59 mL) of fresh lemon juice (about 2 large lemons)
1 inch (2.5 cm) of fresh ginger (cut) or 1 teaspoon (4.2 grams) of ginger powder
1 garlic clove
2 teaspoons (8.4 grams) of turmeric powder
3 tablespoons (44 mL) of extra virgin olive oil
1 tablespoon (15 mL) of apple cider vinegar
¼ teaspoon (1.05 grams) of black pepper
Salt to taste

steps.headline: Make golden milk for a boost of antioxidants in every sip.
steps.description:
With all those anti-inflammatory and antioxidant powers, it’s no wonder that golden milk is so popular. Use golden milk in place of regular milk to make smoothies or just sip it hot or cold for a sweet, earthy, and creamy pick-me-up. Combine the following ingredients in a medium saucepan over medium heat, whisking it together until it almost reaches a boil (remove it right before):
1.5 cups (350 mL) of light coconut milk (canned is best)
1.5 cups (350 mL) of unsweetened almond milk (plain, or any milk of your choice)
1½  teaspoons (6.3 grams) of turmeric powder
¼ teaspoon (1.05 grams) of ginger powder
¼ teaspoon (1.05 grams) of ground cinnamon (or 1 whole cinnamon stick)
1 tablespoon (15 mL) of coconut oil
1 pinch of ground black pepper
This makes 2 glasses that you can drink immediately (while warm) or serve with ice. Store it in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.

steps.headline: Mix up a turmeric detox broth for soups, gravies, and sauces.
steps.description: Broth is very versatile in the sense that you can use it to flavor a lot of dishes and accompaniments (anything that calls for broth). And adding turmeric to your regular batches of broth will give you all the health benefits it offers. For every 8 cups (1.9 L) of broth, stir in 1-2 teaspoons (4.2-8.4 grams) of turmeric powder. For a rounded flavor, use mustard seed, cumin, coriander, and a little lime juice (for acidity) when you’re making broth from scratch. Add cayenne pepper (which also has antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties) into the broth to spice it up.
